The Twitter Dev account is probably not run by a dev. Their 10 k requests info is not in the developer portal. Only the 10 k Tweets limit. At the same time all other info is written in requests per time frame. But a single request can get you multiple items. And I haven't found a way to sign up yet. Maybe it's not as finished as I assumed at first.

Free tier: Only login and posting.
25 logins per user per day. Post 50 Tweets per day total. 1500 Tweets per month.

Basic tier $100: Read up to 10 k Tweets per month. Post 50 k Tweets per month (limited to 1667 per day total, 100 per user).

More relevant to #fedifinder is the /2/users/:id/following endpoint. It's limited to 500 requests per app and 100 requests per user. Each per day. Each request returns up to 1000 followings. 500 requests would return 500 k accounts per day. 15 million accounts per month. At the moment I am confident that that would be more than enough for Fedifinder. Maybe even without code changes.

If instead of the dev portal the Twitter Dev account is correct, 1000 requests per month would be one million accounts per month. If logins are counted against that limit, only half of that. That may be not enough.

I should be able to know more about the actual fedifinder usage in some days (https://vis.social/@Luca/110111257893659558).

Once again, the communication by Twitter is inconsistent.

title: Why do Arabic fonts appear so small? (and how to fix it) — Alex Strick van Linschoten

last_post.content:
Feeling dumb:
I thought that arabic type appearing tiny was prescriptive, i.e. people prefer arabic to be set smaller than Latin type. Turns out it is descriptive and the result of a technical issue & careless design. Due to larger extenders, arabic type is much smaller set to the same point size as latin. #typography

Method using Lua: in the filter use
function Pandoc (doc)
doc.meta.references = pandoc.utils.references(doc)
doc.meta.bibliography = nil
-- ...
end

This will populate the `references` metadata field with all references in YAML format. We can use that to modify the bibentires after citeproc ran by matching their div IDs to entries in the YAML list.

title: Victory for migrants as judge rules immigration exemption is incompatible with GDPR

last_post.content:
Yesterday the High Court (UK) ruled that the immigration exception is unlawful in the judicial review we brought with the3million.

The exception lets the Home Office and private companies refuse requests by individuals for access to their personal data on the grounds that it might 'prejudice the maintenance of effective immigration control'. This denial can prevent migrants from challenging mistakes in the data and immigration decisions.

#gdpr #ukpolitics

Random Controller of the Day

🕹️ The Bug (Cheetah)
🗓️ 1991
➡️ Amiga, Amstrad, Atari ST, C64, VIC-20, ZX Spectrum +2 / +3

The Cheetah Bug was a micro-switched joystick that featured a short stubby directional stick, two fire-buttons and an autofire function.

The Bug was originally released in a black finish. In 1993, a Green and Red variant, the "Slime Edition" was launched, and a Chrome variant was supposed to be released too.

http://joystick.directory/wiki/The_Bug

httpgd is a very cool #rstats package which enables you to show plots in your web browser. This is useful if you work in #nvim, since the default graphics viewer is very basic. httpgd have all the features you would expect, such as plot history and exporting plots.

Try it:

install.packages("httpgd")
httpgd::hgd()
httpgd::hgd_browse()
plot(cars$speed, cars$dist)

For more info:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i_09TMdc8g8 by @jmbuhr

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxyhmhRVOfw by @brodriguesco

I just realized this post is missing one important issue but it won’t fit under the character limit to have it added in so I’ll add it here.

The number of steps one has to take to create a Mastodon account if they begin at the joinmastodon website is numerous enough that it has undoubtedly deterred many people from joining. One can argue that it acts as a natural filter but if the goal is for more people to join the network, that seems counterintuitive.

Perhaps one way to avoid those lengthy steps is to encourage instance owners to package or promote their instances independently and to their extended communities. Herein lies the irony of a decentralized network relying on a centralized website.

By self promoting the instance and getting people to sign up without having to go to the main Mastodon website, it would remove so many of the barriers or hoops.

This will allow instance owners or admins to run whichever social web platform is the most suitable for the community, which doesn’t have to be Mastodon.

Mastodon may be the current flagship but other social web platforms may fit certain communities better, so instead of saying join Mastodon, instance admins or owners can ask prospective members to join their community which will allow them to do such and such on the platform they use.

It’s early days so there won’t be many mobile or desktop apps for non Mastodon platforms but developers will eventually accomodate if they haven’t already.

Big problem: authors often support claim X with with a citation to paper Y, even though Y has no bearing on X or even directly refutes X.

Estimates suggest that between 5% and 35% (the latter seems too high to me) of scientific citations do this. It's a grave sin, akin to claiming statistical significance when you clearly don't have it. Yet it's very common.

An extreme case: the first citation in the new FLI letter "Pause Giant AI experiments".

A new #Twitter #API announcement. This time it sounds specific enough to get implemented.

- API v1 will be shut down completely
- Free tier allows only the posting of Tweets (1500/month)
- $100 tier gets developers 10 k GET and 50 k POST requests. Edit: Apparently the amount of requests isn't as relevant as in the past. There is a hard 10 k Tweets limit per month.
- No solution for academic research.

This means I have to shutdown https://accountanalysis.app .

I'm currently thinking about possible solutions for #fedifinder. Crowdfunding $100/month seems reasonable. But I would have to add account level caching on the server to be able to help more people migrate. You would upload the followings file from your Twitter data export, get cached matches in realtime and info about unchecked IDs. Every time there are 1000 unchecked IDs, the server requests those through the API and caches the results. A bot could inform you about new matches. At the end of the month remaining requests are used to re-check oldest/most popular IDs.
